image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a black hoodie

items.synopsis: Brett Andrew Button, 58, has been released with strict conditions after being granted bail by Cessnock Local Court on Tuesday morning.

title.children: Bus driver 'happy to be going home' after being granted bail over fatal wedding bus crash

image.altText: Rebecca Mullen

items.synopsis: There have been prayers, candles and a guernsey tribute for the 10 victims of the Hunter Valley wedding bus crash, as local communities grieve loved ones.

title.children: Junior doctor among victims identified as communities left grief-stricken over Hunter Valley crash

image.altText: Gallagher speaks on the senate floor.

items.synopsis: Senator Gallagher fiercely denies she misled parliament over statements she made in relation to Brittany Higgins, telling the Senate that recent events have harmed progress in making parliament safer.

title.children: Katy Gallagher offers full denial to Senate over Brittany Higgins allegations

image.altText: One hand on a laptop's trackpad while another hand holds a credit card

items.synopsis: Fraudulent sites are mimicking real brands, going as far as stealing logos and brand design. Melinda did the checks but they weren't enough — so here are the signs to look out for.

title.children: Fake websites are getting slicker and mimicking real brands. Melinda fell for one and wants others to know the signs

image.altText: Les Turner stands in front of a blue painting

items.synopsis: As debate ramps up around a Voice to Parliament, which aims to give First Nations Australians a say in government policy, Central Land Council CEO Les Turner says it is "a strong point" that the NT government has not sought out land councils' views.

title.children: Land councils say lack of consultation on NT agriculture strategy undermines rights

image.altText: a young brunette woman smiling into the camera

items.synopsis: Twenty-four-year-old Julia-Mary Lane, who is known as JM, has been living in Canada since early January and is heading into her third night in the wilderness of British Columbia.

title.children: Family fears for Australian woman missing after going hiking in Canadian bear country

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

items.synopsis: With only 24 hours in a day, researchers have crunched the numbers and worked out what the average global human day looks like.

title.children: This is what the average human day looks like. How do Australians compare?

image.altText: A woman voting at night at a cardboard polling booth

items.synopsis: Young people are increasingly concerned about the future of the planet and want to have a say, according to organisers of the Make It 16 campaign.

title.children: 'Young people deserve a seat at the table': Campaign to lower the voting age to 16

image.altText: a woman wearing glasses talking into microphones at a press conference

items.synopsis: Kate Jenkins, who led the inquiry into the culture of parliament, says the workplace has improved — but warns of the potential damage being done to victims of sexual assault by recent reporting.

title.children: 'It has changed': Kate Jenkins says parliament culture is getting better

image.altText: A drone shot of rows of houses in Shell Cove, Wollongong's south.

items.synopsis: The value of Australian homes rebounds to $9.9 trillion, but higher interest rates means consumers are more wary of getting into the property market. And the ASX turns higher after US stocks reach a 13-month high.

title.children: Home prices rise but consumers think it's a bad time to buy a house, ASX reverses course

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Queensland has unveiled a record $12.3 billion budget surplus thanks to a rise in coal royalties which generated more than $15 billion in revenue. The money will fund cost of living relief, including a $550 electricity rebate for households, and 15 hours a week of free kindergarten for all four year olds from next year. Queensland treasurer Cameron Dick said the record surplus would be used to pay down debt. "This is the largest budget surplus ever recorded by any state or territory," he said. "Our budget surplus is larger than all but four surpluses delivered by the government of the Commonwealth of Australia, all more than 15 years ago. More from Queensland political reporter Rachel Riga.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queensland's record budget surplus

featuredLink.title: Power bill rebates and free kindy: $1.6b in new cost-of-living relief announced for Queenslanders

children.content: Queensland has unveiled a record $12.3 billion budget surplus thanks to a rise in coal royalties which generated more than $15 billion in revenue.
The money will fund cost of living relief, including a $550 electricity rebate for households, and 15 hours a week of free kindergarten for all four year olds from next year.
Queensland treasurer Cameron Dick said the record surplus would be used to pay down debt.
"This is the largest budget surplus ever recorded by any state or territory," he said.
"Our budget surplus is larger than all but four surpluses delivered by the government of the Commonwealth of Australia, all more than 15
years ago.
More from Queensland political reporter Rachel Riga.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nickel and lithium producer IGO has appointed Ivan Vella as its new chief executive. Mr Vella runs Rio Tinto's aluminium division and will take up his new job in December. He has been with Rio Tinto for 20 years, and was brought in to run the iron ore division after the company destroyed sacred Aboriginal caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara in Western Australia in 2020. Mr Vella will replace IGO's former chief executive Peter Bradford, who died last October. IGO owns nickel, copper and cobalt mines in Western Australia, and in partnership with Tianqi Lithium Corporation, a lithium mine and refining plant.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Rio aluminium boss to run battery minerals producer

children.content: Nickel and lithium producer IGO has appointed Ivan Vella as its new chief executive.
Mr Vella runs Rio Tinto's aluminium division and will take up his new job in December.

He has been with Rio Tinto for 20 years, and was brought in to run the iron ore division after the company destroyed sacred Aboriginal caves at Juukan Gorge in the Pilbara in Western Australia in 2020.
Mr Vella will replace IGO's former chief executive Peter Bradford, who died last October.
IGO owns nickel, copper and cobalt mines in Western Australia, and in partnership with Tianqi Lithium Corporation, a lithium mine and refining plant.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Retail giant Wesfarmers has moved further into healthcare by buying online prescription and telehealth firm InstantScripts. Wesfarmer's subsidiary Australian Pharmaceutical Industries will buy InstantScripts from Bailador Technology Investments for $135 million. Wesfarmers Health managing director, Emily Amos, said InstantScripts will become part of her division. “Over recent years telehealth has emerged as an important service, complementing the care delivered through GP practices, pharmacies and other allied health providers,” Ms Amos said. "InstantScripts provides flexible services that are available at short notice and outside of normal consultation hours, and is accessible to patients in remote areas and those who have difficulty visiting a GP."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Wesfarmers buys InstantScripts

children.content: Retail giant Wesfarmers has moved further into healthcare by buying online prescription and telehealth firm InstantScripts.
Wesfarmer's subsidiary Australian Pharmaceutical Industries will buy InstantScripts from Bailador Technology Investments for $135 million.
Wesfarmers Health managing director, Emily Amos, said InstantScripts will become part of her division.
“Over recent years telehealth has emerged as an important service, complementing the care
delivered through GP practices, pharmacies and other allied health providers,” Ms Amos said.
"InstantScripts provides flexible services that are available at
short notice and outside of normal consultation hours, and is accessible to patients in remote
areas and those who have difficulty visiting a GP."

image.altText: A Caucasian woman in a pink top and black jacket, speaks at the podium of parliament, with her party sitting behind her.

items.synopsis: Federal Housing Minister Julie Collins has offered to amend the Housing Australia Future Fund legislation to guarantee yearly spending in return for Senate crossbench support.

image.altText: Fiona Mardling smiling in a portrait, wearing a blue clinic uniform and a stethscope around her neck.

image.altText: A close up shot of a man wearing glasses and a baseball cap

image.altText: Rear and side of a Victoria Police divisional van. Taken March 2023

image.altText: Queensland budget winners and losers 2021 illustration

image.altText: Ukrainian service members of the 55th Separate Artillery Brigade fire a Caesar self-propelled howitzer towards Russian troops.

image.altText: Two men crouched over a coffin with a woman wrapped in a sheet inside.

image.altText: Half the image is underwater showing fish and mangrove roots, the top half is the mangrove canopy and sun peeking through.

image.altText: A composite image of a bald PNG man with glasses wearing a grey suit and another PNG man wearing a grey cap

image.altText: A man holding a high-tech space cube.

image.altText: A Denver NBA player smiles and puts his hands on his head in celebration after his team wins a title.

image.altText: NSW State of Origin coach, Brad Fittler, holds a ball under his arm as he watches team training.

image.altText: A woman making a coffee in a cafe

items.synopsis: Finger-pointing over what or who is responsible for inflation is gaining momentum. But the cause of and solutions for the issue are very hard to identify, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: 'Militant workers', 'greedy capitalists' or neither — who's really to blame for the inflation crisis?

image.altText: A Golden Globe award, shaped like a globe on a pedestal with a strip of movie film wrapped around it.

items.synopsis: The Hollywood Foreign Press Association (HFPA) sells the Golden Globes to private investors, spelling the end of the embattled non-profit after 80 years of handing out the entertainment awards.

image.altText: A composite image of three people on stage wearing long gowns

items.synopsis: This year's Tony Awards were almost cancelled because of the Writers Guild of America strike blazing through Hollywood. But the show must go on — and so it did.

image.altText: Former president Donald Trump walks up stairs to board a large aircraft with TRUMP written on the side in gold letters.
